none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from T. A. Fuller, circa April 13, 1887
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from T. A. Fuller, circa April 13, 1887
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 25 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: Letter from Texas House Representative Tully A. Fuller to Professor C. B. McInnis at Agricultural and Mechanical College (A&M) seeking information about the college's current condition and faculty views on pending legislation. Fuller requests data to inform himself on matters related to the college and proposed legislative action being considered by the University Regents. The letter reflects contemporary legislative interest in the governance and operations of Texas's land-grant institution.

body.value:
[Seal of The State of Texas]
House of Representatives,
20TH LEGISLATURE.
Austin, [April?] 15 1887

Prof C.B. McInnis
College Station
Dear Sir -

I am satisfied
from what I hear and the position
assumed by University Regents in
their report that legislation will be
attempted effecting the A&m College

As I am not well up in
the condition &c of the college at
present will you favor me with
such data at your command as
will enable me to properly inform
myself - Also your views and that
of the faculty concerning the College
and proposed legislation &c

With my regards I am
Truly Yours
Tully A. Fuller

**Transcription Task Breakdown** Okay, here's the transcription process I've gone through, step-by-step. I'm starting with a handwritten letter from the House of Representatives, and I need to produce an HTML transcription. My task is clear: transcribe faithfully, top-to-bottom, preserving everything as it appears on the page. The guidelines are specific: I'm not allowed to use markdown tables unless the content is tabular, and I need to incorporate particular HTML tags (`a`, `b`, `br`, `i`, `img`, `p`, `small`, `span`, `sub`, `sup`). I am also told to identify structural elements using labels, such as *[Header]*. The seal is mentioned, which I will need to consider. First, I examined the document. It's a letter on official stationery, from the 20th Texas Legislature in Austin. The date looks tricky, with a pencil annotation potentially modifying it. The recipient's name requires close attention. The handwriting is a bit loopy, making the initials of the recipient, "Prof L.L. McInnis" a little difficult. I compared the handwriting of 'C' and 'L' to resolve the initials, noting "C.B. McInnis" due to the way the 'B' is drawn. After more comparison, the history appears to be more "L.L." McInnis. I re-evaluated the date. Next, I worked through the letter's content. I took note of the key points: the writer's concern about pending legislation affecting A&M College, a request for information from the recipient, and the closing remarks. The spelling of "effecting" was important to confirm. I was meticulous in cross-checking each word to catch everything. Once I had a good grasp of the content, I began a rough transcription. I kept the date, recipient, salutation, paragraphs, closing, and signature in order. I made sure to note the pencil text, "April?". I began mapping how the text would fall into the appropriate HTML tags, including the header elements. I then went through a refinement phase. I looked at the date again. I closely re-examined the initials, confirming "C.B." The word "effecting" I had to confirm, the "A&M" initials required special attention because of the messy pen strokes, but the content confirmed my belief, and I made notes about the structure. I identified that the "7" in 1887 was added in a different handwriting. Next, I formatted it using HTML. Because there is a line break, the break is preserved. I considered the use of the `` tag for the seal image but decided to include the seal's textual representation, *[Seal of The State of Texas]*, because I didn't have an image source. Paragraphs were mapped to `

` tags, with `
` tags representing line breaks within each paragraph. The right alignment was a key element. After doing some self-corrections on the layout and tags, I did a final review. I re-read the transcribed text for accuracy. I focused on the words: "Prof C.B. McInnis", "A&M" and "effecting". It's a meticulous process, but attention to detail is the most important thing. I checked to be sure to use HTML as requested. I also rechecked my assumptions about the name initials, ultimately settling on "C.B. McInnis". The handwriting of the initial "A" in "A&M" was also scrutinized, but I decided it was A. I used the correct use of capitals for the "20TH LEGISLATURE." Finally, I'm ready to produce the HTML output!
